The vast majority of caught entries followed a "(hr|hcr|rr|rt|fm) ([0-9a-z]+) box ([0-9a-z]+)" or similar formula. We had one un-resolvable entry, one jumbled/disorganized entry, one that had a (likely unintentionally) omitted 'rr' prefix, one that had a secondary address unit value for the 'box', and several 'box' streets which were found to be valid. We processed our rural formula by shifting the 'box' values to street numbers (first part of street address) unless otherwise specified. We performed our modifications.

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  # Initiate subset-specific notes columns
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_msc = NA_character_ 
  ) |> 
  dplyr::mutate(
    # Copy into notes, if modifying
    client_msc = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        !stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, 
          '(strong box|box rd|box s dr|box t dr|box k ln)'
          ),
      client_street_address,
      client_msc
    ),
    # Shift single value to secondary value
    client_street_address_scnd1_val = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'county road'),
      stringr::str_match(client_street_address, 'box ([0-9]+)$')[,2],
      client_street_address_scnd1_val
    ),
    # Point-modification of addresses
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id,
      dplyr::case_when(
        # Remove box that was a secondary unit
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'county road') ~
          stringr::str_remove(
            client_street_address,
            stringr::str_match(client_street_address, '(box [0-9]+)$')[,2]
          ),
        # Un-resolvable entry with attempted modification
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '(i)$') ~ paste0(
          stringr::str_match(
            client_street_address, 
            '^(?:rr) ([0-9]+) box ([0-9]+) (?:i)$'
            )[,3], 
          ' i-', 
          stringr::str_match(
            client_street_address, 
            '^(?:rr) ([0-9]+) box ([0-9]+) (?:i)$'
            )[,2],
          ' s'
          ),
        # Add 'rr' prefix
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '^([0-9] box [0-9]+)') ~
          paste0('rr ', client_street_address),
        # Fix order of jumbled entry
        stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, 
          '(box ([0-9]+) ([a-z]) highway)'
          ) ~ paste0(
            stringr::str_match(
              client_street_address, 
              '^(.+?) (box ([0-9]+) ([a-z]) highway)'
              )[,2], 
            ' box ', 
            stringr::str_match(
              client_street_address, 
              '^(.+?) (box ([0-9]+) ([a-z]) highway)'
              )[,4], 
            stringr::str_match(
              client_street_address, 
              '^(.+?) (box ([0-9]+) ([a-z]) highway)'
              )[,5]
            ),
        TRUE ~ client_street_address
      ),
      client_street_address
    ),
    # Reorder entries so "box" value is the street number
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '^(.+?) box ([0-9a-z]+)$') &
        !stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, 
          '(strong box|box rd|box s dr|box t dr|box k ln)'
          ),
      paste0(
        stringr::str_match(
          client_street_address, 
          '^(.+?) box(?: )?([0-9a-z]+)$'
          )[,3], 
        ' ', 
        stringr::str_match(
          client_street_address, 
          '^(.+?) box(?: )?([0-9a-z]+)$'
          )[,2]
        ),
      client_street_address
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
  # Shift notes data into overall client notes field
    client_notes = ifelse(
      # If client_notes has no text, just add client_msc (if not empty)
      is.na(client_notes),
      ifelse(!is.na(client_msc),
        paste("Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes),
      # Otherwise, paste if client_notes exists to avoid pasting "NA" in

        paste(client_notes, "; Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes
      )
    )
  ) |>
  # Remove temporary columns
  dplyr::select(-c(client_msc))
```

```{r}
        TRUE ~ client_street_address
      ),
      client_street_address
    )
  ) |>

  # Shift notes data into overall client notes field
    client_notes = ifelse(
      # If client_notes has no text, just add client_msc (if not empty)
      is.na(client_notes),
      ifelse(!is.na(client_msc),
        paste("Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes),
      # Otherwise, paste if client_notes exists to avoid pasting "NA" in

      ifelse(

        paste(client_notes, "; Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes
      )

  # Remove temporary columns
  dplyr::select(-c(client_msc))
```

#### Maximum Character Length (30 characters)

The maximum character length of the `client_street_address` field was 30 characters, indicating that values at this maximum length may have experienced truncation that might significantly influence the effectiveness of batch processing. We had 558 such entries, most of which appeared to be street names that were named in tribute to famous figures such as Martin Luther King Jr.

```{r}
checking <- aps |>
  dplyr::filter(nchar(client_street_address) == 30

format(nrow(checking), big.mark=',')
# [1] 558
```

##### Martin Luther King Jr

The name "Martin Luther King Jr" is 21 characters in length, leaving little room for additional characters. We had 310 such rows. While various permutations of the name were examined, using AND logic for matches of "mart" and "king" appeared to catch all relevant values while minimizing any errant inclusions.

```{r}
checking <- aps |>
  dplyr::filter(nchar(client_street_address) == 30
  ) |>
  dplyr::filter(
    stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'mart')  & stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'king')
  )

format(nrow(checking), big.mark=',')
# [1] 310
```

We processed all entries. Care was given to maintain suffixes, where possible.

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  # Initiate subset-specific notes columns
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_msc = NA_character_ 
  ) |> 
  dplyr::mutate(
    # Copy to Notes
    client_msc = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id,
      client_street_address,
      client_msc
    ),
    # Remove "DR" prefix from specific values
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id & 
        (stringr::str_starts(client_zip_code,'751')|
           stringr::str_starts(client_zip_code,'765')) &
        !stringr::str_ends(client_street_address, 'p'),
      stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, 'dr mart', 'mart'),
      client_street_address
    ),
    # Convert name to "mlk jr" for all values
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id,
      stringr::str_replace(
        client_street_address, '(mart.+?)$', 'mlk jr'
        ),
      client_street_address
    ),
    # Add Street Suffixes
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id & !is.na(client_zip_code),
      dplyr::case_when(
        # ZIP 773, Special N/S designation
        (stringr::str_starts(client_zip_code,'773') & 
            stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '04')
          ) ~ paste(client_street_address, 'pl n'),
        (stringr::str_starts(client_zip_code,'773') & 
            stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '25')
          ) ~ paste(client_street_address,'pl s'),
        # 'HWY'
        stringr::str_starts(client_zip_code,'766') ~ 
          paste(client_street_address, 'hwy'),
        # 'ST'
        stringr::str_starts(client_zip_code,'778') ~ 
          paste(client_street_address, 'st'),
        # 'DR'
        (stringr::str_starts(client_zip_code, '776')|
           (stringr::str_starts(client_zip_code, '765') &
              stringr::str_detect(client_city, 'pl')
            )) ~ paste(client_street_address, 'dr'),
        # 'AVE'
        (stringr::str_starts(client_zip_code, '765') &
              stringr::str_detect(client_city, 'lt')
            ) ~ paste(client_street_address, 'ave'),
        (stringr::str_starts(client_zip_code, '756') &
              stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '17')
            ) ~ paste(client_street_address, 'ave'),
        # 'BLVD'
        !stringr::str_ends(
          client_street_address, 
          '(hwy|blvd|ave|st|pl n|pl s|dr)'
          ) ~ paste(client_street_address, 'blvd'),
        TRUE ~ client_street_address
      ),
      client_street_address
      )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
  # Shift notes data into overall client notes field
    client_notes = ifelse(
      # If client_notes has no text, just add client_msc (if not empty)
      is.na(client_notes),
      ifelse(!is.na(client_msc),
        paste("Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes),
      # Otherwise, paste if client_notes exists to avoid pasting "NA" in 
      # anything
      ifelse(
        !is.na(client_msc),
        paste(client_notes, "; Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes
      )
    )
  ) |>
  # Remove temporary columns
  dplyr::select(-c(client_msc))
```

We removed the terms "interstate", "state", and references to "access road" (which was impacted by truncation). The only state referenced was Texas, which we changed to the 2-character abbreviation to minimize nonsingificant string distancing.

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  # Initiate subset-specific notes columns
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_msc = NA_character_

    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, '(interstate|state)'
        ),
      stringr::str_remove_all(
        client_street_address,
        '(interstate|state)'
      ),
      client_street_address
    ),
    # Remove references to access road
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, '(acc|access rd|access r)$'
        ),
      stringr::str_remove_all(
        client_street_address,
        '(acc|access rd|access r)$'
      ),
      client_street_address
    ),
    # Convert "Texas" to "tx"
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, '(texas)'
        ),
      stringr::str_replace(
        client_street_address,
        '(texas)',
        'tx'
      ),
      client_street_address
    ),
    # Convert "Highway" to "hwy"
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, '(highway)'
        ),
      stringr::str_replace(
        client_street_address,
        '(highway)',
        'hwy'
      ),
      client_street_address
    ),
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    # Standardize white spaces to a single white space
    client_street_address = stringr::str_replace_all(
      client_street_address, "( {2,})", " "
      ),
    # Remove leading and trailing white spaces
    client_street_address = stringr::str_trim(
      client_street_address, side = 'both'
      )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
  # Shift notes data into overall client notes field
    client_notes = ifelse(
      # If client_notes has no text, just add client_msc (if not empty)
      is.na(client_notes),

        paste("Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes),

      ifelse(
        !is.na(client_msc),
        paste(client_notes, "; Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes
      )
    )
  ) |>
  # Remove temporary columns
  dplyr::select(-c(client_msc))
```

There were 19 variants (38 entries) which did not require any modification. One variant was not able to be fully resolved as it provided a directional address along a road which did not appear to exist as named; a best attempt was given to resolve as closely as possible, without losing data fidelity. 

There were entries that contained "farm to market", which was standardized to "ftm"; for one of these, the term "north" was additionally standardized to "n" to minimize non-significant string distancing. Another appeared to lose street name data due to truncation, which was corrected as best as the team was able using street mapping (Google Maps).

Other entries referenced counties by name, which were abbreviated to reduce non-significant string distances.

There were entries that referenced a county jail, a cemetery, and a care facility. These were updated to separate business names from street addresses, where possible.

The other entries required minor modifications, such as the standardization of a military ranking within a street name or re-introduction of truncated street name values less than 5 characters in length. A single entry had a city, state, and partial zip code removed.

#### Standardization of Common Street Address Components

There are multiple components of street names which are both common and long in string-length in a way that may inflate non-significant string distances and "muffle" significant differences. This includes components such as "country road", "private road", and "farm to market", all of which may have multiple equivalent abbreviations (inflated non-signficant string distances) and convey meaningful differences in a separate component (numerical "suffix", such as "County Road 123" and "County Road 124" requiring omission of the "County Road" component to appropriately convey in string-distancing that these are separate streets).

As such, we examined the patterns of these values in our data set and sought to standardize the values to short abbreviations to maximize the meaningfulness of string-distances in street address values for our fuzzy matching algorithms.

##### (CR) County Road

There were several observations identified in prior examination and standardization which referenced county roads. While roads are formally standardized to "COUNTY ROAD" according to [USPS standards](https://pe.usps.com/text/pub28/28apf.htm), we chose to standardize to "CR" to reduce non-significant string distances. We identified the following values as likely referencing "county road" in addressing: county road, country road, cnty, cr, -cr, cr road, cr rd, county rd, country rd, co rd, and co road.

We also examined all values which contained "county" or "country" for additional values, though none were identified in this screen.

There were 14,631 rows remaining with street address values containing one of our chosen components.

```{r}
cr_regex <- paste0(
  '(county road|country road|cnty| cr |-cr|cr rd|cr road|',
  'county rd|country rd| co rd| co road)'
  )

checking <- aps |>
   dplyr::filter(stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, cr_regex))

format(nrow(checking), big.mark=',')
# [1] "14,631"
```

```{r}
cr_regex <- paste0(
  '(county road|country road|cnty| cr |-cr|cr rd|cr road|',
```

###### Primary Standardization of County Road Values

We chose to standardize all "County Road" variants to "cr". This was done to avoid non-significant string distances, as "county road" would simultaneously inflate the non-significant distances between "123 county road 98" and "123 cr 98", but also suppress the significant distances between "123 county road 98" and "123 county road 76".

We first carefully copied modified values into our subset-specific notes column. We excluded a single street name which was not actually a county road (but would be caught in the regular expression to standardize these roads).

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  # Initiate subset-specific notes columns
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_msc = NA_character_ 
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    # Add to notes if any modifications are being made
    client_msc = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id & !(
        stringr::str_starts(
          client_street_address,
          'pr'
          )
      ) & 
      # Exclude specific street name
      !stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '(old county|old country)'),
    client_street_address,
    client_msc
    )
  ) 
  

```

There were four street addresses (reflected in 6 rows) which provided two street addresses within a single row. We isolated these values before we proceeded further with modifications.

```{r}

  dplyr::filter(
    case_id %in% checking$case_id &
      stringr::str_detect(
        client_street_address, 
        '(eva|prair|is lo|22 county road s)'
        )
  )
```

We then modified our small set of duplicated rows to reflect the alternate street name values.

```{r}
modified_set <- modified_set |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_street_address = case_when(
      stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'eva') ~
        stringr::str_remove(client_street_address, 'county .+?$'),
      stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'is lo') ~
        stringr::str_remove(client_street_address,' cr [0-9]+?$'),
      stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'prair') ~
        stringr::str_remove(client_street_address, ' cr [0-9]+'),
      stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '22 county road s') ~ 
        stringr::str_replace(
          client_street_address,
          'county.+$',
          'cherokee ridge cir'),
      TRUE ~ client_street_address
    )
  )
```

Our point-processing included the removal of a secondary unit value ("Annex", confirmed to not be a street suffix but an unusual secondary unit value), removal of superfluous repetitions of "road" with "cr", removal of "county road" that was not valid within a street name, removal of "private road" when inappropriate to include, and resolution of variants of "[letter]-cr" equivalents. We also performed the corresponding changes to the rows which were previously extracted for duplication. 

We them performed our bulk standardization of "county road" (and variants) to "cr", followed by an additional point-fix altering a street name which appeared to be a "cr" equivalent (but which was not, on inspection).

###### Standardization of County Name Components of County Road Values

Several county roads feature the name of the county as part of the street name to differentiate similar streets in nearby counties. For example, Harris county may have a "Harris CR 123" and Travis county may have a "Travis CR 123". It is common practice to abbreviate these county names to 1 or 2 letter values. No official standardization of these abbreviations was found in our literature review search, so we chose to adopt an internal standardization.

We first identified and isolated the 50 entries which contained this pattern.

```{r}
checking <- aps |>
  dplyr::filter(
    stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '(cr|county|country)')
    ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    temp_addr = ifelse(
      !is.na(client_county),
      paste(client_county, '(cr|county|country)'),
      NA_character_
      )
  ) |>
  dplyr::filter(stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, temp_addr)) |>
  dplyr::select(-c(temp_addr))

format(nrow(checking), big.mark=',')
# [1] "50"
```

We performed our standardization on these 50 observations. There were observations for several counties that either required no changes or were unresolvable which were omitted from modification. Additionally, there were some rows which required modification using our point-fix set to protect PHI.

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  # Initiate subset-specific notes columns
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_msc = NA_character_ 
  ) |> 
  dplyr::mutate(
    # Copy to Notes if modifications made
    client_msc = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        !(client_county %in% c(
          'duval', 'milam', 'rains', 'hays', 'mclennan', 'travis', 'upshur'
          )),
      client_street_address,
      client_msc
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    # Resolve point-mutation set 
    client_street_address_name = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        client_street_address %in% point_fixes$original_street_addr,
        dplyr::case_when(
          client_street_address == point_fixes$original_street_addr[1] ~ 
            point_fixes$addr_name[1],
          TRUE ~ client_street_address_name
        ),
        client_street_address_name
      ),
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        client_street_address %in% point_fixes$original_street_addr,
        dplyr::case_when(
          client_street_address == point_fixes$original_street_addr[1] ~ 
            point_fixes$street_addr[1],
          TRUE ~ client_street_address
        ),
        client_street_address
      ),
    # Remaining modifications
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        !(client_county %in% c(
          'duval', 'milam', 'rains', 'hays', 'mclennan', 'travis', 'upshur',
          'dallas'
          )),
      dplyr::case_when(
        client_county == 'anderson' ~ stringr::str_replace(
          client_street_address,
          'anderson cr',
          'an-cr'
          ),
        client_county == 'comanche' ~ stringr::str_replace(
          client_street_address,
          'comanche cr',
          'c-cr'
          ),
        client_county == 'henderson' ~ stringr::str_replace(
          client_street_address,
          'henderson cr',
          'h-cr'
          ),
        client_county == 'hill' ~ stringr::str_replace(
          client_street_address,
          'hill cr',
          'h-cr'
          ),
        client_county == 'van zandt' ~ stringr::str_replace(
          client_street_address,
          'van zandt cr',
          'vz-cr'
          ),
        TRUE ~ client_street_address
      ),
      client_street_address
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
  # Shift notes data into overall client notes field
    client_notes = ifelse(
      # If client_notes has no text, just add client_msc (if not empty)
      is.na(client_notes),
      ifelse(!is.na(client_msc),
        paste("Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes),
      # Otherwise, paste if client_notes exists to avoid pasting "NA" in 
      # anything
      ifelse(
        !is.na(client_msc),
        paste(client_notes, "; Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes
      )
    )
  ) |>
  # Remove temporary columns
  dplyr::select(-c(client_msc))
```

##### (FTM) Farm to Market

There were several observations identified in prior examination and standardization which referenced farm to market. While these roads are formally standardized to "FM" according to [USPS standards](https://pe.usps.com/text/pub28/28apf.htm), we chose to standardize to "FTM" to reduce non-significant string distances and any ambiguity in targeting these entries. We identified the following values as likely referencing "farm to market road" in addressing: farm, market, ftm, and fm.

There were 10,187 rows remaining with street address values containing one of our chosen components.

```{r}
checking <- aps |>
  dplyr::filter(
    stringr::str_detect(client_street_address,'(farm|market|ftm|fm)'))

format(nrow(checking), big.mark=',')
# [1] "10,187"
```

We divided our processing into four primary "chunks":
1. Broad checks for matches for "farm dr", "farm st", "farmhouse rd", or any street name with "farmer" anywhere in the value; secondary check in this section for "ftm" anywhere in the value
2. Any street name that did not start with a number
3. Matches for "fm"
4. Any remaining potential match observations, such as "spelled out" variants ("farm market road', "farm to market", etc)

###### Broad catch checks: ‚Äú(farmer|farm dr|farm st|farmhouse rd)‚Äù and "ftm" (101 rows)

We first verified several values that appeared to be valid non-"farm to market" street names. This included streets with the word "farmers", "farm dr", "farm st", and "farmhouse drive."

We had 101 observations that were caught by our regular expression check. On examining all 101 values, we determined that only one represented a potential farm to market road; unfortunately, this observation did not include a full street address and was thus unable to be resolved. The remaining 100 values were non-"farm to market" street names, and would thus be excluded from any standardization.

```{r}
      "(farmer|farm dr|farm st|farmhouse rd)"
    )
  )

format(nrow(subset), big.mark=',')
# [1] "101"
```

We also checked for values which contained our target standardization of "FTM". There were 18 observations which met this standard, 9 of which were farm to market roads which had already received our modification. The remaining 9 observations appeared to be valid street names containing words with "ftm" within a word. No changes were necessary for these values.

```{r}

  dplyr::filter(
    stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "ftm")
  )

format(nrow(subset), big.mark=',')
# [1] "18"
```

###### Non-numeric first character (23 rows)

We then verified the values that did not start with a number.

We had 23 observations that satisfied our conditions. Unfortunately, all 23 of these observations did appear to be valid farm to market roads, though they lacked the house number prefix required to be a valid address. As such, they were unable to be resolved and would thus be excluded from detailed modifications.

```{r}
  )
```

We standardized any mention of a farm to market road in this subset to "ftm", to resolve the entries in our processing pathway. We also re-created the "checking" subset, to ensure the data was accurate to our procesing.

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  # Initiate subset-specific notes columns
```

###### "FM" (9,083 rows)

We next verified values which directly contained the USPS standard abbreviation of "FM". However, at 9,083 matches, this was a prohibitively large subset to manually examine each potential observation.

```{r}
subset <- checking |>
  # Exclude prior "chunk"
  dplyr::filter(
    !(stringr::str_detect(
        client_street_address,
        "(farmer|farm dr|farm st|farmhouse rd|ftm)"
      ) | stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "^[^0-9]")
    )
  ) |>
  # Define this "chunk"
  dplyr::filter(
    stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "fm")
  )

format(nrow(subset), big.mark=',')
# [1] "9,083"
```

In exploration, we were able to identify several broad patterns we could eliminate from a more complete examination and point-modification set. Five (5) patterns validated as plausible valid farm to market addresses:
- "^[0-9]+ fm [0-9]+$" (5,202 rows)
- "^[0-9]+ [nwse] fm [0-9]+$" (1,004 rows)
- "^[0-9]+ fm [nwse] [0-9]+$" (1 row)
- "^[0-9]+ fm [0-9]+ [nwse]$" (997 rows)
- "^[0-9]+ [nwse] fm [0-9]+ [nswe]$" (24 rows)

We combined all of these values into a single regular expression:
1. "^[0-9]+ [nwse]{0,2}[ ]{0,1}fm[ ]{0,1}[nwse]{0,2} [0-9]+[ ]{0,1}[nwse]{0,2}$"

This expression caught an additional observation, which was verified to be valid without further modification (total of 7,229 rows validated).

We additionally identified one (1) pattern that led only to unresolvable farm to market addresses (pattern 2), and one (1) pattern led only to non-farm to market addresses which had "fm" in a word of the street name (pattern 3):
  
2. "fm$" (3 rows)
3. "fm[^0-9 -]" (236 rows)

This reduced our subset to 1,615 rows.

```{r}
elim_regexes <- c(
  "^[0-9]+ [nwse]{0,2}[ ]{0,1}fm[ ]{0,1}[nwse]{0,2} [0-9]+[ ]{0,1}[nwse]{0,2}$",
  "fm$",
  "fm[^0-9 -]"
  )

subset <- checking |>
  # Exclude prior "chunk"
  dplyr::filter(
    !(stringr::str_detect(
        client_street_address,
        "(farmer|farm dr|farm st|farmhouse rd|ftm)"
      ) | stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "^[^0-9]")
    )
  ) |>
  # Define this "chunk"
  dplyr::filter(
    stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "fm")
  ) |>
  # Remove matches to the verified patterns
  dplyr::filter(
     !(stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, elim_regexes[1]) |
       stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, elim_regexes[2]) |
       stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, elim_regexes[3])
     )
  )

format(nrow(subset), big.mark=',')
# [1] "1,615"
```

We first checked for variants that were similar to our elimination regular expressions, but mixed any letters into the numerical components; we found values which required stripping a letter-based unit value. We also identified the values which would otherwise match our primary regular expression but contained "rd" or "road" at the end of the string, corrected by removing this extraneous information (1,101 rows). We performed our modifications, and then re-processed our subset selection (which would trim these newly cleaned values from further examination).

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  # Initiate subset-specific notes columns
  dplyr::mutate(

          )|

           )|
          stringr::str_detect(
            client_street_address, "^[0-9]+ fm [0-9]+( rd| road)?$"

           stringr::str_detect(
             client_street_address,

      client_street_address,

    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(

    client_street_address_scnd1_val = ifelse(
      case_id %in% subset$case_id &
        (stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, "^[0-9a-z]+ [nwse] fm [0-9a-z]+$"
          )|
         stringr::str_detect(
           client_street_address, "^[0-9a-z]+ fm [0-9a-z]+ [nwse]$"
           )
         ),
      stringr::str_match(client_street_address, "^[0-9]+?([a-z]+) ")[,2],
      client_street_address_scnd1_val
    ),
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% subset$case_id &
        (stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, "^[0-9a-z]+ [nwse] fm [0-9a-z]+$"
          )|
         stringr::str_detect(
           client_street_address, "^[0-9a-z]+ fm [0-9a-z]+ [nwse]$"
           )
         ),
      stringr::str_remove(
        client_street_address,
        stringr::str_match(client_street_address, "^[0-9]+?([a-z]+) ")[,2]),
      client_street_address
    ),
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% subset$case_id &
        stringr::str_detect(
           client_street_address, 
           paste0(
             "^[0-9]+ [nwse]{0,2}[ ]{0,1}fm[ ]{0,1}[nwse]{0,2} ",
             "[0-9]+[ ]{0,1}[nwse]{0,2}(rd|road| rd| road)$")
           ),
      stringr::str_remove(client_street_address,"(rd|road| rd| road)$"),
      client_street_address
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
  # Shift notes data into overall client notes field
    client_notes = ifelse(
      # If client_notes has no text, just add client_msc (if not empty)
      is.na(client_notes),
      ifelse(!is.na(client_msc),
        paste("Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes),
      # Otherwise, paste if client_notes exists to avoid pasting "NA" in 
      # anything
      ifelse(
        !is.na(client_msc),
        paste(client_notes, "; Street Addr:", client_msc),

  # Remove temporary columns
  dplyr::select(-c(client_msc))

checking <- aps |>

subset <- checking |>

  dplyr::filter(
```

We had 509 remaining observations, which we examined through further use of regular expressions. These pieces are defined as follows:

1. Any street address where "fm" had neither a space nor hyphen separating it from another value, which was corrected through adding a white space (10 rows)
2. Any street address where "fm" had a hyphen on either side, which was corrected by replacing with a white space (11 rows)
3. Values with road specifiers, which were mostly valid but did receive minor point fixes, targeted with "(loop|spur|bypass|old|rr)" (42 rows)
4. Values with "road", targeted with "(road|rd| road| rd)". The "road" values were removed, though some observations received additional point fixes (386 rows).
  -   We examined rows that *ended* in this "road" value, targeted with "fm(road|rd| road| rd)$" (1 row)
  -   We examined rows that started with a combination of letters and numbers (excluding those with only numbers in the first "chunk") (9 rows)
  -   We examined rows that had a letter *after* "fm", excluding those that ended with a "road" variant (14 rows)
  -   We examined rows that had a letter *before* "fm", excluding those that had a combination of letters and numbers in the chunk immediately preceeding "fm" (3 rows)
  -   We then examined any remaining "road" matches
5. We examined any rows that ended in letters, that were not part of prior fixes
6. We then examined the few remaining values.
  
We applied our fixes, standardized any potentially valid mention of a farm to market road to "ftm", and standardized our white spaces. We then re-created our "checking" subset to ensure it contained accurate, updated data.

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  # Initiate subset-specific notes columns
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_msc = NA_character_ 
  ) |> 
  dplyr::mutate(
    # Copy to notes if any changes are being made
    client_msc = ifelse(
      case_id %in% subset$case_id,
        client_street_address,
        client_msc
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    # Resolve addresses with unit issues
      client_street_address_scnd1_val = ifelse(
        case_id %in% subset$case_id,
          dplyr::case_when(
            stringr::str_detect(
              client_street_address, 
              "^[0-9a-z]{3,4} fm [0-9]+(rd|road| rd| road)$"
              ) ~
              stringr::str_match(
                client_street_address, 
                "^[0-9]+([a-z]) fm")[,2],
            stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "0 road ") ~
              stringr::str_match(client_street_address, " ([0-9a-z]+)$")[,2],
            stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "e trl ") ~ 
              stringr::str_match(client_street_address, "([0-9a-z]+)$")[,2],
            stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, " cabin ") ~ 
              stringr::str_match(client_street_address, "([0-9a-z]+)$")[,2],
          TRUE ~ client_street_address_scnd1_val
          ),
        client_street_address_scnd1_val
      ),
    client_street_address_scnd1_type = ifelse(
      case_id %in% subset$case_id &
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "e trl "),
      "trlr",
      client_street_address_scnd1_type
    ),
    client_street_address = ifelse(
        case_id %in% subset$case_id,
          dplyr::case_when(
            # Separating "fm" adjacent to other entries (no hypen or space)
            stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "[^ -]fm") ~ 
              stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, "fm", " fm"),
            stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "fm[^ -]") ~ 
              stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, "fm", "fm "),
            # Converting hyphens on "fm" to white spaces
            stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "fm-") ~ 
              stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, "fm-", "fm "),
            # House numbers with unit issues
            stringr::str_detect(
              client_street_address, 
              "^[0-9a-z]{3,4} fm [0-9]+(rd|road| rd| road)$"
              ) ~ stringr::str_remove(
                client_street_address, 
                stringr::str_match(
                  client_street_address,
                  "^[0-9]+([a-z]) fm")[,2]
            ),
            stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "e trl ") ~ 
              stringr::str_remove(client_street_address, "( trl .+?)$"),
            stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, " cabin ") ~ 
              stringr::str_remove(client_street_address, "( cabin .+?)$"),
            stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, " spot") ~ 
              stringr::str_remove(client_street_address, " spot"),
          # Rename non-fm street
          stringr::str_detect(
            client_street_address, 
            "^(.+?) fm [a-z] ([a-z]+)" 
            ) ~
            paste0(
              stringr::str_match(
                client_street_address, 
                "^(.+?) fm [a-z] ([a-z]+)"
                )[,2],
              " sme",
              stringr::str_match(
                client_street_address, 
                "^(.+?) fm [a-z] ([a-z]+)"
                )[,3]
              ),
          # Reorder an unusual address
          stringr::str_detect(
            client_street_address, 
            "([0-9]+) fm ([a-z]+) ([0-9]+) rd$") ~
            paste(
              stringr::str_match(
                client_street_address, 
                "([0-9]+) fm ([a-z]+) ([0-9]+) rd$"
                )[,2],
              stringr::str_match(
                client_street_address, 
                "([0-9]+) fm ([a-z]+) ([0-9]+) rd$"
                )[,3],
              "fm",
              stringr::str_match(
                client_street_address, 
                "([0-9]+) fm ([a-z]+) ([0-9]+) rd$"
                )[,4]
              ),
          # Remove "Bypass Rd" from street name
          stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "bypass rd") ~ 
              stringr::str_remove(client_street_address, " bypass rd"),
          # Remove unit number
          stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "0 road ") ~ 
              stringr::str_remove("9393 fm 1960 road 216", " ([0-9a-z]+)$"),
          # Adjust location of a cardinal direction
          str_detect(client_street_address, "n[0-9]+") ~ 
            paste0(
              str_match(client_street_address, "^(.+? )fm n(.+?)$")[,2],
              "n fm ",
              str_match(client_street_address, "^(.+? )fm n(.+?)$")[,3]
            ),
          TRUE ~ client_street_address
          ),
        client_street_address
    ),
    # Remove road or rd from street addresses
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% subset$case_id &
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "(road|rd| road| rd)"),
      stringr::str_remove(client_street_address, "(road|rd| road| rd)"),
      client_street_address
    ),
    # Standardize "fm" to "ftm" in subset entries
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% subset$case_id &
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, " fm "),
      stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, " fm ", " ftm "),
      client_street_address
    ),
    # Standardize "fm" to "ftm" in exclusion regex entries
    client_street_address = ifelse(

         ) &
        !(stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "[^ -]fm")|
            stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, "fm[^ -]")
        ),
      stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, " fm", " ftm"),
      client_street_address
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
  # Shift notes data into overall client notes field
    client_notes = ifelse(
      # If client_notes has no text, just add client_msc (if not empty)
      is.na(client_notes),
      ifelse(!is.na(client_msc),
        paste("Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes),
      # Otherwise, paste if client_notes exists to avoid pasting "NA" in 
      # anything
      ifelse(
        !is.na(client_msc),
        paste(client_notes, "; Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes
      )
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    # Consolidate multiple white spaces into a single white space  
    client_street_address = 
      stringr::str_replace_all(client_street_address, "( {2,})", " "),
    # Trim leading and trailing white spaces
    client_street_address = 
      stringr::str_trim(client_street_address, side = 'both')
  ) |> 
  # Remove temporary columns
  dplyr::select(-c(client_msc))
```

##### (PR) Private Road, to (pvtr)

There were several observations identified in prior examination and standardization which referenced private roads. While these roads are not formally listed in [USPS standards](https://pe.usps.com/text/pub28/28apf.htm) for street address abbreviations, we chose to standardize to "pvtr" to reduce non-significant string distances and any ambiguity in targeting these entries. We identified the following values as likely referencing "private road" in addressing: "(priv|pvt)". We also included a specific subset of matches for 'pr'.

There were 1,455 rows remaining with street address values containing one of our chosen components, after excluding a single observation with a non-USA address.

```{r}
checking <- aps |>
  dplyr::filter(
    stringr::str_detect(client_street_address,'(priv|pvt)') |
      # Narrow down possible "pr" matches
      (str_detect(client_street_address, 'pr') &
        (str_detect(client_street_address, 'pr$') |
          str_detect(client_street_address, ' (cpr|gpr|prc|prv|pr[0-9])') |
          str_detect(client_street_address, '^pr') |
          str_detect(client_street_address, ' pr ')
        )
       )
    ) |>
  dplyr::filter(is.na(client_country))

format(nrow(checking), big.mark=',')
# [1] "1,455"
```

Values which followed the expected "[house number] private road [road number]" pattern, expressed in a regular expression as "^[0-9]+ (private road|private rd|pr) [0-9]+$", were assumed to be potentially valid. As such, the 1,271 rows which met this standard were standardized without additional examination.

Of the remaining 184 rows, we made several point-fixes. There were two observations that had the street numbers pulled as secondary address unit values, due to the street number including a pound (#) symbol; these were rejoined. Other observations had unit numbers in the form of letters in the house number, spacing issues connecting the "pr" directly to the numbers without any gap, had unusual extra letters, or had "private" together with a street name that was not actually a private road. We performed our point fixes and standardized our values.

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  # Initiate subset-specific notes columns
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_msc = NA_character_ 
  ) |> 
  dplyr::mutate(
    # Copy to Notes if modifications made
    client_msc = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        !stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, 
          '(road dr|way pvt|va jr|te dr|et ln|ex ln)$'
          ),
      client_street_address,
      client_msc
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        !stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, 
          '(road dr|way pvt|va jr|te dr|et ln|ex ln)$'
          ),
      dplyr::case_when(
        # Adding truncated part of address name
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'aro$') ~ 
          paste(client_street_address, 'solis st'),
        # Fixing spacing error
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'pr[0-9]') ~ 
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, 'pr', 'pr '),
        # Reclaiming incorrectly trimmed "secondary unit" values
        stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, 
          '4[0-9] (private rd|pr)$'
          ) ~ paste(client_street_address, client_street_address_scnd1_val),
        TRUE ~ client_street_address
      ),
      client_street_address
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_street_address_scnd1_val = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        !stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, 
          '(road dr|way pvt|va jr|te dr|et ln|ex ln)$'
          ),
      dplyr::case_when(
        # Removing secondary values that have been reclaimed
        stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, 
          paste0(
            '4[0-9] (private rd|pr) ',
             client_street_address_scnd1_val,
            '$'
            )
          ) ~ NA_character_,
        # Extracting secondary values from addresses
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '^[0-9]+[a-j] p') ~
          stringr::str_match(client_street_address, '^[0-9]+([a-j]) p')[,2],
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'd 22[0-9]+[a-z]$') ~
          stringr::str_match(client_street_address, 'd 22[0-9]+([a-z])$')[,2],
        TRUE ~ client_street_address_scnd1_val
      ), 
      client_street_address_scnd1_val
    ),
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        !stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, 
          '(road dr|way pvt|va jr|te dr|et ln|ex ln)$'
          ),
      dplyr::case_when(
        # Simple Standardizations
        stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, 
          "^[0-9]+ (private road|private rd|pr) [0-9]+$"
          ) ~
          stringr::str_replace(
            client_street_address, 
            "(private road|private rd|pr)", 
            "pvtr"
            ),
        # Converting a PR to CR
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '0 pvt rd') ~ 
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, 'pvt rd', 'cr'),
        # Removing "private road" from values where it is unnecessary
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '(ickor|stes)') ~ 
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, " private", ""),
        # Replace odd extra letters around "pr" entries
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '(gpr|cpr|prv)') ~ 
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(gpr|cpr|prv)', 'pvtr'),
        # Point-fix of a specific odd extra letter
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '(prc )') ~ 
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(prc )', 'pvtr c'),
        # Additional point-fix of an odd extra letter
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '^([0-9]+)n') ~
          stringr::str_replace(
            client_street_address, 
            stringr::str_match('135n private road 1512', '^([0-9]+)n')[,1],
            stringr::str_match('135n private road 1512', '^([0-9]+)n')[,2]
            ),
        # Broader street name changes - first with our point-fix data set
        client_street_address == point_fixes$original_street_addr[3] ~
          point_fixes$street_addr[3],
        # Then with R code
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'f pr$') ~
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, 'pr$', 'prairie'),
        # Observations where "private" possibly refers to a person - "pvt"
        stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, 
          paste0(
            '(ron rd|sie|aro|lis st|ley lane|kin rd|nn rd|ino rd|an rd',
            '|kin road|el rd|age cir|nt road|nt rd)$'
            )
          ) ~ stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, 'private', 'pvt'),
        # Removing shifted secondary unit values from addresses
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '^[0-9]+[a-j] p') ~
          stringr::str_remove(client_street_address,
            stringr::str_match(client_street_address, '^[0-9]+([a-j]) p')[,2]),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'd 22[0-9]+[a-z]$') ~
          stringr::str_remove(
            client_street_address,
            paste0(stringr::str_match(
              client_street_address, 'd 22[0-9]+([a-z])$')[,2], 
              "$"
              )
            ),
        TRUE ~ client_street_address
      ),
      client_street_address
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    # Standardize final entries
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        !stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address, 
          '(road dr|way pvt|va jr|te dr|et ln|ex ln)$') &
        !stringr::str_detect(
        client_street_address, 
        '(county road|country road)'),
      dplyr::case_when(
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '(private|privat)') ~
          stringr::str_replace(
            client_street_address,
            '(private road|private rd|privat road)', 
            'pvrt'),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '^pr ') ~
          stringr::str_replace(
            client_street_address,
            '^pr', 
            'prvt'),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, ' pr$') ~
          stringr::str_replace(
            client_street_address,
            'pr$', 
            'prvt'),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, ' pr ') ~
          stringr::str_replace(
            client_street_address,
            ' pr ', 
            ' prvt '),
        TRUE ~ client_street_address
      ),
      client_street_address
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
  # Shift notes data into overall client notes field
    client_notes = ifelse(
      # If client_notes has no text, just add client_msc (if not empty)
      is.na(client_notes),
      ifelse(!is.na(client_msc),
        paste("Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes),
      # Otherwise, paste if client_notes exists to avoid pasting "NA" in 
      # anything
      ifelse(
        !is.na(client_msc),
        paste(client_notes, "; Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes
      )
    )
  ) |>
  # Remove temporary columns
  dplyr::select(-c(client_msc))
```

##### Cardinal Directions

There remained several common elements of street addresses which could be standardized. However, our final bulk standardization came for cardinal directions, which we trimmed to a single letter.

There were 11,048 rows remaining with street address values containing one of our chosen components.

```{r}
checking <- aps |>
  dplyr::filter(
    stringr::str_detect(
      client_street_address,
      '(northeast|northwest|southeast|southwest|east|west|north|south) '
      ) |
      stringr::str_detect(
        client_street_address,
        ' (northeast|northwest|southeast|southwest|east|west|north|south)')
    )

format(nrow(checking), big.mark=',')
# [1] "11,048"
```

We made our modifications.

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  # Initiate subset-specific notes columns
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_msc = NA_character_ 
  ) |>

      client_msc
    )

  dplyr::mutate(
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id,
      dplyr::case_when(
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'northwest[ -]') ~
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(northwest)[ -]', 'nw '),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'northeast[ -]') ~
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(northeast)[ -]', 'ne '),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'southwest[ -]') ~

        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'southeast[ -]') ~
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(southeast)[ -]', 'se '),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'north[ -]') ~
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(north)[ -]', 'n '),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'south[ -]') ~
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(south)[ -]', 's '),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'east[ -]') ~
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(east)[ -]', 'e '),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'west[ -]') ~
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(west)[ -]', 'w '),
        TRUE ~ client_street_address
      ),
      client_street_address
    ),
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id,
      dplyr::case_when(
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'northwest[ -]') ~
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(northwest)[ -]', 'nw '),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'northeast[ -]') ~
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(northeast)[ -]', 'ne '),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'southwest[ -]') ~
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(southwest)[ -]', 'sw '),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'southeast[ -]') ~
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(southeast)[ -]', 'se '),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'north[ -]') ~
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(north)[ -]', 'n '),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'south[ -]') ~
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(south)[ -]', 's '),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'east[ -]') ~
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(east)[ -]', 'e '),
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'west[ -]') ~
          stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, '(west)[ -]', 'w '),
        TRUE ~ client_street_address
      ),
      client_street_address
    ),
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id,
      dplyr::case_when(
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '[ -](northwest)$') ~

        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '[ -](north)$') ~

        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '[ -](south)$') ~

        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '[ -](east)$') ~

        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '[ -](west)$') ~
```

### QC Checks

We then turned towards our final quality control checks.

#### Secondary Address Fields

We examined our separated secondary address fields to ensure no information beneficial in street addresses were inappropriately separated.

We first checked the single entry which had two separated values.

```{r}
checking <- aps |>
  dplyr::filter(
    !is.na(client_street_address_scnd2_val)
  )

format(nrow(checking), big.mark=',')
# [1] "1"
```

We did not find any errant separation. 

We next checked the 199 entries which had secondary values which contained any character other than a number.

```{r}
checking <- aps |>
  dplyr::filter(
    stringr::str_detect(client_street_address_scnd1_val, '[^0-9]')
  )

format(nrow(checking), big.mark=',')
# [1] "199"
```

We identified three entries which specifically had a truncated portion of the city name in the secondary address value field.

```{r}
checking <- aps |>
  dplyr::filter(
    stringr::str_detect(
      client_street_address_scnd1_val, 
      '^([0-9a-z]+) ([0-9a-z]+)$'
      )
  ) |>
  dplyr::filter(
    stringr::str_detect(
      client_city, 
      stringr::str_match(
        client_street_address_scnd1_val, 
        '^[0-9a-z]+ ([0-9a-z]+)$')[,2]
      ) &
      nchar(stringr::str_match(
        client_street_address_scnd1_val, 
        '^[0-9a-z]+ ([0-9a-z]+)$')[,2]
      ) > 1
  )

format(nrow(checking), big.mark=',')
# [1] "3"
```

We removed those truncated values.

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_street_address_scnd1_val = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id,
      stringr::str_remove(
        client_street_address_scnd1_val,
        ' ([0-9a-z]+)$'
      ),
      client_street_address_scnd1_val
    )
  ) 
```

There were two remaining values which had two secondary values in one.

```{r}
checking <- aps |>
  dplyr::filter(
    stringr::str_detect(client_street_address_scnd1_val, '(bed|bldg)')
  )

format(nrow(checking), big.mark=',')
# [1] "2"
```

We separated those values, concluding the QC of separated secondary address values.

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_street_address_scnd2_type = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id,
      stringr::str_match(client_street_address_scnd1_val, '(bed|bldg)')[,2],
      client_street_address_scnd2_type
    ),
    client_street_address_scnd2_val = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id,
      stringr::str_match(
        client_street_address_scnd1_val, 
        '(bed|bldg) ([0-9a-z]+)$'
        )[,3],
      client_street_address_scnd2_val
    ),
    client_street_address_scnd1_val = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id,
      stringr::str_match(client_street_address_scnd1_val, '^([0-9a-z]+) ')[,2],
      client_street_address_scnd1_val
    )
  )
```

#### Street Addresses

We then examined our street addresses. First, we looked for street addresses which included the ZIP Code. All five entries required modification.

```{r}
checking <- aps |>
  dplyr::filter(
    stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, client_zip_code)
  )

format(nrow(checking), big.mark=',')
# [1] "5"
```

We made our modifications.

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  # Initiate subset-specific notes columns
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_msc = NA_character_,
    # Copy modified addresses into notes
    client_msc = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id,
      client_street_address,
      client_msc
    )
  ) |> 
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id,
      stringr::str_match(client_street_address, '^(.+? (ave|st))')[,2],
      client_street_address
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
  # Shift notes data into overall client notes field
    client_notes = ifelse(
      # If client_notes has no text, just add client_msc (if not empty)
      is.na(client_notes),
      ifelse(!is.na(client_msc),
        paste("Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes),
      # Otherwise, paste if client_notes exists to avoid pasting "NA" in 
      # anything
      ifelse(
        !is.na(client_msc),
        paste(client_notes, "; Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes
      )
    )
  ) |>
  # Remove temporary columns
  dplyr::select(-c(client_msc))
```

We next examined any street addresses which included the state; we found no modifications required in the 275 matching entries.

```{r}
checking <- aps |>
  dplyr::filter(
    stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, client_state)
  )

format(nrow(checking), big.mark=',')
# [1] "275"
```

Third, we looked for street addresses which ended with some portion of the city. While the vast majority of the 27 entries were caused by matches between the "st" suffix and city names, a few unusual entries were identified in this set. However, we did not find any entries we could modify to benefit fuzzy matching.

```{r}
checking <- aps |>
  dplyr::filter(
    stringr::str_detect(
      client_city,
      stringr::str_match(client_street_address, ' (.+?)$')[,2]
    )
  )

format(nrow(checking), big.mark=',')
# [1] "27"
```

We then checked the 3,252 entries where the city was directly included in the street name in some from. This led us to discover a single entry which required our point-fix file to adjust without using PHI.

```{r}
checking <- aps |>
  dplyr::filter(
    stringr::str_detect(
      client_street_address,
      client_city
    )
  )

format(nrow(checking), big.mark=',')
# [1] "3,252"
```

We made this fix.

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_street_address_name = ifelse(
      client_street_address == point_fixes$original_street_addr[4],
      point_fixes$addr_name[4],
      client_street_address_name
    ),
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      client_street_address == point_fixes$original_street_addr[4],
      point_fixes$street_addr[4],
      client_street_address
```

##### Format Violations

We then turned towards street addresses which did not meet expected formatting. First, we looked at the 519 entries which lacked a numeral, without being a missing value.

```{r}
checking <- aps |>
  dplyr::filter(
    !is.na(client_street_address) &
    !stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '[0-9]')
  )

format(nrow(checking), big.mark=',')
# [1] "519"
```

There was a single value that could be fixed without use of PHI (as it was converting a word to a numeral). The remaining values which could be corrected had a strong match, such as an exact business name match. The remainder were unable to be resolved.

We applied our corrections.

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  # Initiate subset-specific notes columns
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_msc = NA_character_ 
  ) |> 
  dplyr::mutate(
    # Copy to Notes if modifications made
    client_msc = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        (
          stringr::str_starts(client_street_address, "ten")|
            (client_street_address %in% point_fixes$original_street_addr)
          ),
      client_street_address,
      client_msc
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        stringr::str_starts(client_street_address, "ten"),
      stringr::str_replace(client_street_address, "ten", "10"),
      client_street_address
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
  # Shift notes data into overall client notes field
    client_notes = ifelse(
      # If client_notes has no text, just add client_msc (if not empty)
      is.na(client_notes),
      ifelse(!is.na(client_msc),
        paste("Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes),
      # Otherwise, paste if client_notes exists to avoid pasting "NA" in 
      # anything
      ifelse(
        !is.na(client_msc),
        paste(client_notes, "; Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes
      )
    )
  ) |>
  # Remove temporary columns
  dplyr::select(-c(client_msc))

for (i in seq(5,25)){

}
```

While the vast majority of these entries had been determined to be unresolvable, a few required point-fixes.

We made our modifications

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  # Initiate subset-specific notes columns
  dplyr::mutate(
    client_msc = NA_character_ 
  ) |> 
  dplyr::mutate(
    # Copy to Notes if modifications made
    client_msc = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        (stringr::str_detect(
          client_street_address,
          paste0(
            '(tx |at [0-9]|u[0-9]+ |y [0-9]+ [0-9]{2}',
            '|r[0-9]+ n|auto zone|laquinta inn)'
            )
          ) | (client_street_address %in% point_fixes$original_street_addr)
         ),
      client_street_address,
      client_msc
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    # Value with secondary address component
    client_street_address_scnd1_val = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'y [0-9]+ [0-9]{2}'),
      stringr::str_match(client_street_address, '([0-9]+)$')[,2],
      client_street_address_scnd1_val
    ),
    # Values with Business Names
    client_street_address_name = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, '(auto zone|laquinta inn)'),
      dplyr::case_when(
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'auto zone') ~ 'auto zone',
        stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'laquinta inn') ~ 
          'la quinta inn',
        TRUE ~ client_street_address_name
      ),
      client_street_address_name
    ),
    
    client_street_address = ifelse(
      case_id %in% checking$case_id &
      stringr::str_detect(
        client_street_address,
        paste0(
          '(tx |at [0-9]|u[0-9]+ |y [0-9]+ [0-9]{2}',
          '|r[0-9]+ n|auto zone|laquinta inn)'
          )
        ),
       dplyr::case_when(
         # Value with secondary address component
      stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'y [0-9]+ [0-9]{2}') ~
        stringr::str_remove(client_street_address,
           stringr::str_match(client_street_address, '( [0-9]+)$')[,2]
           ),
      # Clean up an otherwise unresolvable entry
      stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'tx ') ~ 
        stringr::str_match(client_street_address, '^(tx.+?)tx')[,2],
      # Remove prefix values
      stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'at [0-9]') ~ 
        stringr::str_remove(client_street_address, 'at '),
      stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'u[0-9]+ ') ~ 
        stringr::str_remove(client_street_address, 'u'), 
      stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'r[0-9]+ n') ~ 
        stringr::str_remove(client_street_address, 'r'),
      # Remove business names
      stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'auto zone') ~ 
        stringr::str_remove(client_street_address, 'auto zone '),
      stringr::str_detect(client_street_address, 'laquinta inn') ~ 
        stringr::str_remove(client_street_address, 'laquinta inn '),
      TRUE ~ client_street_address
      ),
      client_street_address
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
  # Shift notes data into overall client notes field
    client_notes = ifelse(
      # If client_notes has no text, just add client_msc (if not empty)
      is.na(client_notes),
      ifelse(!is.na(client_msc),
        paste("Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes),
      # Otherwise, paste if client_notes exists to avoid pasting "NA" in 
      # anything
      ifelse(
        !is.na(client_msc),
        paste(client_notes, "; Street Addr:", client_msc),
        client_notes
      )
    )
  ) |>
  # Remove temporary columns
  dplyr::select(-c(client_msc)) 

for (i in seq(26,31)){
  # Point fix location names
  aps[
    !is.na(aps$client_street_address) &
    aps$client_street_address == point_fixes$original_street_addr[i],
    ]$client_street_address_name <- point_fixes$addr_name[i]
  # Point fix actual addresses
  aps[
    !is.na(aps$client_street_address) &
    aps$client_street_address == point_fixes$original_street_addr[i],
    ]$client_street_address <- point_fixes$street_addr[i]
}
```

## Flagging Unresolvables

Finally, we flagged our unresolvable entries, as they may benefit from additional checks during match reviews.

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    flag_unresolvable = ifelse(
      case_id %in% unresolvables$case_id, TRUE, FALSE
    )
  )
```

## Final Standardization

We then performed final standardization of white spaces, including enforcing that empty strings were converted to missing values.

```{r}
aps <- aps |>
  dplyr::mutate(dplyr::across(c(
                    'client_street_address', 'client_city', 'client_state', 
                    'client_county', 'client_street_address_name',
                    'client_street_address_scnd1_val', 
                    'client_street_address_scnd1_type',
                    'client_street_address_scnd2_val', 
                    'client_street_address_scnd2_type'
                    ), 
                    ~stringr::str_replace_all(.x, "( {2,})", " ")
                  )) |>
  dplyr::mutate(dplyr::across(c(
                    'client_street_address', 'client_city', 'client_state', 
                    'client_county', 'client_street_address_name',
                    'client_street_address_scnd1_val', 
                    'client_street_address_scnd1_type',
                    'client_street_address_scnd2_val', 
                    'client_street_address_scnd2_type'
                    ), 
                    ~ifelse(.x == "", NA_character_, .x)
                  ))
```
